message.raw:
Changed the way we lock AO objects. Now we set the limits of the adjustment to be equal to the value (so you can't change it)

This way you can always access the lock/unlock context menu as the widget is always sensitive!

message.raw:
Moved the novatech over to the new output classes. Abort buffered looks to have a bug in it - it will reprogram the novatech to the last line of the experimental run, instead of the previous static values.
This will be pretty easily fixed, I'll just have to ask Shaun first about some of the behaviour of the thing so I know my fix will work.

message.raw:
Bugfixed pulseblaster.py, main.pyw and output_classes.py to the point where BLACS actually runs again.

Also made BLACS shutdown a bit more cleanly, with less errors being raised at shutdown.

Also made a failure to connect to the analysis server halt further attempts at next startup, but setting the submit button to inactive (which gets saved as front panel state)
message.html:
Bugfixed pulseblaster.py, main.pyw and output_classes.py to the point where BLACS actually runs again.

Also made a failure to connect to the analysis server halt further attempts at next startup, but setting the submit button to inactive (which gets saved as front panel state)

message.raw:
Smart programming for the PulseBlaster. Now checks amplitude, freq, phase and pulse program arrays before programming.
Makes no atttempt to program only the modified amplitude registers. If one amplitude changes there's a complete reprogram of the amlitude registers.
There is presently no way to force a fresh reprogram. Will copy the Novatech DDS9M's implementation of this shortly.

message.raw:
Moved the pulseblaster hardware interface over to the new output classes, which are in output_classes.py.
Also implemented the new pulseblaster buffered programming scheme, which should fix the instability we saw with the previous scheme.
Also moved the buffered programming into the worker class (it was previously in pythonlib/hardware programming/pulseblaster.py).
This commit was a massive cleanup, removing a lot of code made redundant by the change in both buffered and static programming methods.

This is all completely untested as I am not near a control PC! Will test tomorrow.
message.html:
Moved the pulseblaster hardware interface over to the new output classes, which are in output_classes.py.
Also implemented the new pulseblaster buffered programming scheme, which should fix the instability we saw with the previous scheme.
Also moved the buffered programming into the worker class (it was previously in pythonlib/hardware programming/pulseblaster.py).
This commit was a massive cleanup, removing a lot of code made redundant by the change in both buffered and static programming methods.

This is all completely untested as I am not near a control PC! Will test tomorrow.

Moved the pulseblaster hardware interface over to the new output classes, which are in output_classes.py.
Also implemented the new pulseblaster buffered programming scheme, which should fix the instability we saw with the previous scheme.
Also moved the buffered programming into the worker class (it was previously in pythonlib/hardware programming/pulseblaster.py).
This commit was a massive cleanup, removing a lot of code made redundant by the change in both buffered and static programming methods.

This is all completely untested as I am not near a control PC! Will test tomorrow.

message.raw: Few minor changes and bugfixes to queue manager. Need to debug a collision happening where PFI0 of the NI6363 is still an output at the start of a run, and thus doesn't get clock ticks for a bit, causing the experiment to have incorrect timing. Will debug soon

Looks like we have about one second of overhead in between experiments at the moment.

message.raw:
BLACS now handles connecting to the analysis server gracefully, with the ability to turn on and off submission to the server, change host, check connectivity and save and load settings automatically at start and close.
Post-run submission requires testing on Windows

message.raw:
Fixed bugs with NI PCI 6733 and 6363. Turns out if there wasn't any buffered digital output, the clock signal wouldn't be used properly for the analogue output. This was because the static-mode DO had ownership of the PFI which was being used for clocking.

So now when there is no DO, some empty DO is created. We can make this better in the future by having the task not take ownership of the PFI in the first place. In fact I'll do that soon, it's just complicated by the fact that the port/line syntax and PFI refer to the same terminals, so I have to work out which to skip over.
message.html:
Fixed bugs with NI PCI 6733 and 6363. Turns out if there wasn't any buffered digital output, the clock signal wouldn't be used properly for the analogue output. This was because the static-mode DO had ownership of the PFI which was being used for clocking.

So now when there is no DO, some empty DO is created. We can make this better in the future by having the task not take ownership of the PFI in the first place. In fact I'll do that soon, it's just complicated by the fact that the port/line syntax and PFI refer to the same terminals, so I have to work out which to skip over.

Fixed bugs with NI PCI 6733 and 6363. Turns out if there wasn't any buffered digital output, the clock signal wouldn't be used properly for the analogue output. This was because the static-mode DO had ownership of the PFI which was being used for clocking.

So now when there is no DO, some empty DO is created. We can make this better in the future by having the task not take ownership of the PFI in the first place. In fact I'll do that soon, it's just complicated by the fact that the port/line syntax and PFI refer to the same terminals, so I have to work out which to skip over.

values.message:
Fixed bugs with NI PCI 6733 and 6363. Turns out if there wasn't any buffered digital output, the clock signal wouldn't be used properly for the analogue output. This was because the static-mode DO had ownership of the PFI which was being used for clocking.

So now when there is no DO, some empty DO is created. We can make this better in the future by having the task not take ownership of the PFI in the first place. In fact I'll do that soon, it's just complicated by the fact that the port/line syntax and PFI refer to the same terminals, so I have to work out which to skip over.

message.raw:
Workaround to prevent collisions between h5 writes from the camera system and reads in BLACS from other devices.
Camera transitions to buffered mode after all other devices have finished doing so. This change should be reverted once the camera no longer makes writes. By design, no writing should happen until transition_to_static at the end of an experiment.
message.html:
Workaround to prevent collisions between h5 writes from the camera system and reads in BLACS from other devices.
Camera transitions to buffered mode after all other devices have finished doing so. This change should be reverted once the camera no longer makes writes. By design, no writing should happen until transition_to_static at the end of an experiment.

message.raw: BLACS now deletes the connection table of the settings file prior to saving front panel state on shutdown. This causes the conenction table to be rewritten, even if it has changed. Otherwise if it has changed, the functions that save the front panel state refuse to do so due to the mismatch in connection tables.

message.raw:
Added move up, down, top and bottom functions for reordering the queue.
Since drag and drop didn't seem to work in Windows anyway, I've gotten rid of it for reordering and turned on 'rubber banding' instead, which is clicking and dragging to select multiple files.

message.raw:
FIxed a bug in the multi-notebook setup where a restarted tab would not remove itself from the correct notebook.
This was possibly the cause of a segfault we saw earlier.
Tabs can now restart in-place no matter what notebook they're in!
All I changed was to have tabs update self.notebook to self._toplevelget_parent() whenever close() was called on them.

message.raw:
Changes to queue operations: reruns, repeat, reordering.
You can now queue up an experiment that has already been run, or that is already in the queue. In either case a new h5 file is made and queued up for a rerun of the experiment.
You can also put the queue in 'repeat' mode, which will cause an experiment to be put back on the bottom of the queue once it completes (which triggers a rerun to be made from it, of course)
You can also reorder queued experiments with drag and drop.
Some minor prettification of the UI was also done :)
message.html:
Changes to queue operations: reruns, repeat, reordering.
You can now queue up an experiment that has already been run, or that is already in the queue. In either case a new h5 file is made and queued up for a rerun of the experiment.
You can also put the queue in 'repeat' mode, which will cause an experiment to be put back on the bottom of the queue once it completes (which triggers a rerun to be made from it, of course)
You can also reorder queued experiments with drag and drop.
Some minor prettification of the UI was also done :)

summary.html:
Changes to queue operations: reruns, repeat, reordering.
You can now queue up an experiment that has already been run, or that is already in the queue. In either case a new h5 file is made and queued up for a rerun of the experiment.
You can also put the queue in 'repeat' mode, which will cause an experiment to be put back on the bottom of the queue once it completes (which triggers a rerun to be made from it, of course)
You can also reorder queued experiments with drag and drop.
Some minor prettification of the UI was also done :)

values.message:
Changes to queue operations: reruns, repeat, reordering.
You can now queue up an experiment that has already been run, or that is already in the queue. In either case a new h5 file is made and queued up for a rerun of the experiment.
You can also put the queue in 'repeat' mode, which will cause an experiment to be put back on the bottom of the queue once it completes (which triggers a rerun to be made from it, of course)
You can also reorder queued experiments with drag and drop.
Some minor prettification of the UI was also done :)

message.raw: Tabs now call their own close_tab method when destroyed, instead of waiting for finalise_quit to do it, and the window doesn't hide until BLACS has actually quit, so that you can see which tabs are closing quickly and which time out and get killed.
message.html: Tabs now call their own close_tab method when destroyed, instead of waiting for finalise_quit to do it, and the window doesn't hide until BLACS has actually quit, so that you can see which tabs are closing quickly and which time out and get killed.

message.raw:
Removed all print statements and added some logging.
Fixed a (nother) bug where the queue manager ate CPU cycles in a while loop.
Fixed a bug where a gtk call was made without the gtk lock.
Gave some variables more descriptive names
Removed redundant 'try, except' blocks where the exception was to be raised anyway.
Removed redundant imports no longer required due to work being pushed into subprocesses

message.raw:
Added function which creates a copy of a h5 file in its pre-run (freshly compiled) state.

The function is currently in main.pyw as part of the BLACS class, and is called clean_h5_file.

message.raw:
Can now open a file from the file>open menu item. The h5 file will be added to then end of the queue.
Also fixed some bugs with the queue manager. The manager would wait until timeout if there was an error condition on one of the tabs, now it stops immediately if there is an error. Also it previously massively chewed up CPU cycles in a while loop waiting on transition_to_buffered for each tab. I inserted a time.sleep, but this is still poor form and I'll soon replace with blocking/notification type things.

message.raw:
Fixed bug where upon exiting table mode the Novatech would be programmed to the values it had prior to entering table mode, rather than its last value in table mode.
Implemented a few changes to table mode call to allow new "smart" programming

message.raw:
Modified the saving of front panel states to also save the connection table.

We now provide the option to overwrite the front panel state in an existing h5 file, providing the connection tables match. If no connection table is present, we save the existing connection table in.

There is also a silent save feature which we will use at the start of each experiment run which doesn't popup dialog boxes with messages in!

message.raw:
Changed stop times to t=1, since labscript now throws an error if stop(t=0) is called.
This is so that all runs have a minimum of two clock ticks, the number required by the NI cards' bufferend output.
